LIKE AND SHARE: The Spring-Ford Area School District is proud to announce that four Spring-Ford Area High School students have been recognized as 2021 National Merit Scholarship Program Semifinalists!

Congratulations to Gaurav Chawla, Anshika Gupta, Farnaz A. Khandaker, and Jupjowt Singh

Over 1.5 million juniors in about 21,000 high schools entered the 2021 National Merit Scholarship Program by taking the 2019 Preliminary SAT/National Merit Scholarship Qualifying Test (PSAT/NMSQT®), which served as an initial screen of program entrants. From the approximately 16,000 Semifinalists, about 15,000 are expected to advance to the Finalist level, and in February they will be notified of this designation. All National Merit Scholarship winners will be selected from this group of Finalists.

On August 17, 2020 the Spring-Ford Board of School Directors approved changes to the 2020-2021 School Calendar. The first day of school will now be Tuesday, September 8, 2020 and the tentative last day of school will be June 22, 2021. If approved by PDE for the Flexible Instruction Day Program, the tentative last day of school will move to June 17, 2021. In addition, the In-Service day scheduled for October 12, 2020 will be moved to September 4, 2020, making October 12, 2020 a normal school day for students. This change moves the last day of the first marking period to November 11, 2020.

Click here for more information and to learn about Flexible Instruction Day: https://www.spring-ford.net/about-spring-ford/departments/messages/~board/messages-from-dr-goodin/post/calendar-update

Today we join our neighbors throughout Montgomery County in recognizing Juneteenth. Earlier this week, the Montgomery County Board of Commissioners declared Juneteenth an Official Holiday.

On this day in 1865, Union Army General Gordon Granger read federal orders in Galveston, Texas, that all previously enslaved people in Texas were free – more than two years after President Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation. However, this was not the end of slavery in the United States. People enslaved in Union-held territory were not freed until the passage of the 13th Amendment several months later on December 18, 1865.

Click here for an article titled “What Is Juneteenth? How to Explain the History of the Holiday to Kids” from Parents.com: https://www.parents.com/holiday/what-is-juneteenth-explaining-the-history-of-the-holiday-to-kids/

As you may be aware, many of the measures required to halt the spread of COVID-19 have led children to become isolated from teachers, counselors, and other mandated reporters. In addition, social distancing has limited contact with peers and other trusted confidants. This isolation combined with increased stresses in the home make clear the need to provide a resource for those who feel unsafe or who are concerned about the safety of a friend.

To this end, the Attorney General’s office has repurposed and promoted the Safe2Say app and helpline as a tool available to students to report concerns regarding child abuse. Many schools and students are already very familiar with this program created in response to school violence.

Reach Safe2Say Online: https://www.safe2saypa.org or
Download the App: https://www.safe2saypa.org/download/ or
Call the Helpline: 1-844-SAF2SAY

Senior Shout Out to Spencer Friedrich 👨‍🎓! We could not be any more proud of our son, our hero! Spencer was diagnosed with T-Cell Leukemia in the 10th grade. He was being examined after getting a concussion in a science class, when his nurse noticed inflammation on his neck and ordered a blood test. Spencer missed hundreds of days of school over the next 2 years due to chemotherapy, hospital stays and just not feeling good, all while still managing to make honor roll every semester. Spencer's love of music helped him through some very dark times. He is finishing his chemotherapy this year and heading off to the University of Pittsburgh in the fall to begin the next part of his life. Live your dreams! Love your biggest fans, Dad, Mom and Mason❤

The 2020 Census is Coming! Did you know that the last U.S. Census Bureau was conducted in 2010? When you fill out the Census you help to determine how many seats your state gets in congress and also help to ensure that Montgomery County receives its fair share of the billion’s of dollars of federal funding to support things like:

✔️Child Care
✔️Nutrition, School Lunch and Breakfast Programs
✔️Career, Technical and Workforce Training
✔️Title I, Special Education and Federal PELL Grants
✔️Medicaid and Children’s Health Insurance
✔️Head Start, and many other programs.

With just a 5% undercount in the 2020 Census Montgomery County would stand to lose 73 million dollars of these funds each year for the next 10 years. It is critical that everyone is counted.

By April 1, 2020, every home will receive an invitation to participate in the 2020 Census. You may complete the Census online, by phone, or by mail. Please complete the census for your family and encourage your friends, relatives and neighbors to do the same!

Spring-Ford Area High School Broadcast students are about to kick off the 10 Day Film Challenge!

The 10 Day Film Challenge is an intense and invigorating 10 school days in which teams of students make a movie—write, film, edit and score it—in just 10 school days during their film class periods only!

On Day 1, the Challenge will release to the students the character including his/her backstory, a prop, a line of dialogue, a cinematic technique and genre that must be included in their movie. Then, 10 school days later, a 3-4 minute movie must be complete. Finally, the best films, depending upon the state, will be shown at a local theater or online as part of an awards ceremony.

In 2011, the 10 Day Film Challenge began with three NJ high schools. By 2019, it had grown to 130 high schools and impacting 3,800 student filmmakers from 17 states and 8 countries outside the USA.
